title: True or False: English Grammar Basics
description: Test your knowledge of basic English grammar rules.

questions.question: The sentence 'She don't like pizza' is grammatically correct.
questions.explanation: The correct form should be 'She doesn't like pizza' because 'she' is third person singular and requires 'doesn't'.

questions.question: In English, adjectives always come before nouns.
questions.explanation: While adjectives usually come before nouns (e.g., 'red car'), they can also come after linking verbs (e.g., 'The car is red').

questions.question: The past tense of 'go' is 'went'.
questions.explanation: 'Went' is indeed the correct past tense form of the irregular verb 'go'.

questions.question: You can use 'a' before words that start with vowel sounds.
questions.explanation: You should use 'an' before words that start with vowel sounds (e.g., 'an apple', 'an hour').

questions.question: The word 'information' is countable in English.
questions.explanation: 'Information' is an uncountable noun in English. You cannot say 'informations' or 'an information'.

questions.question: Double negatives are acceptable in standard English.
questions.explanation: In standard English, double negatives are considered incorrect. Instead of 'I don't know nothing', use 'I don't know anything'.

questions.question: The present perfect tense describes actions that happened at a specific time in the past.
questions.explanation: The present perfect tense (have/has + past participle) describes actions with relevance to the present, often without specifying when they occurred.

questions.question: All English words that end in '-ly' are adverbs.
questions.explanation: While many adverbs end in '-ly', some adjectives also end in '-ly' (e.g., 'friendly', 'lonely', 'lovely').
